column1: Damoh is a city in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh.The city is 80KM away from Sagar Division. It is famous for Jainism pilgrimage site Kundalpur (Bade Baba Temple). The district is surrounded by Sagar in the West
column2: Narsinghpur and Jabalpur in the South
column4: Panna & Katni in the east. It is the administrative headquarters of Damoh District.

column1: Stone Age tools have been found in Singrampur Valley and it is believed that the area has been inhabited for thousands of years. According to legend
column2: Damoh was named for the Queen of Narvar Rani Damyanti
column3: the wife of Raja Nal. Around the 5th century
column4: it was part of the empire of Guptas of Pataliputra. This has been evidenced by plaques and coins
column5: and monuments from the reigns of Samudragupta
column7: and Skandgupta. From the 8th to 12th centuries
column8: some parts of the Damoh district were in the Chedi Empire
column9: ruled by the Kalchuri dynasty from its capital Tripuri. The temple at Nohta demonstrates Kalchuri's influence in the 10th century. Some regions of the district were under the Chandels of the Jejak-Bhukti.

column1: Around the beginning of the 14th century
column2: the administrative centre of the Chanderi province of the Khalji dynasty was moved to Damoh.

column1: The era of Muslim rule began in the 14th century. Stone carvings at Salaiya and Batiyagarh mention Khalji and Tuglaq Sultans. The Sultan of Malwa later annexed the region.
In the last quarter of the 15th century
column2: Sangram Shah of the Gond dynasty annexed the region into his empire organized around 52 forts. This was an era of peace and prosperity for the region. In Singrampur
column3: Rani Durgawati attained martyrdom battling against the Mughal Empire
column4: represented by its General Asaf Khan and his army.

column1: Bundelas entered the region for a brief time span
column2: after which Marathas took over in 1732. Marathas remained in control until the British annexed the Marathas kingdom after the death of Peshwa in 1888. The Diwanji ki Talaiya and the Ram Mandir were constructed by the Maratha administrators.

column1: Damoh took part in the struggle for independence from the British. Under the leadership of Thakur Kishore Singh of Hindoria
column7: and Govind Rao were among those who took part in the 1857 revolt.

column2: Damoh became part of Central Provinces under the British Empire in India and was demarcated as a separate district. By 1867
column3: Damoh was constituted as a municipality with a population of about two million. The same year it was connected by railway to Jabalpur and Allahabad.

column1: Damoh suffered from famine in 1896-97 and 1900. By 1899 the India Midland Railway had completed the construction of Sagar–Damoh link and Damoh–Katni links. Freedom fighter Seth Govind Das was jailed in Damoh in 1923
column2: and wrote a number of Hindi plays while imprisoned. In 1929
column4: the first such visit by a Digambar Muni to Damoh after several centuries.In 1933
column6: Sagar University was established as the region's primary centre for higher education.

column2: with India's independence from British Raj
column3: the Central Provinces were reorganized as the state of Madhya Pradesh. The town of Damoh had its first-degree college established in 1961 by Shiksha Prasar Samiti

column1: Damoh city has a Nagar Paliaka Parishad with the elected head Mrs. Malti Asati. tarun rathi is the current DM & Collector for the Damoh District. The current Member of Legislative Assembly from Damoh constituency is Shri Rahul Singh

In the City Tourism is the big source of economy. Tourist comes from across the world to Jainism pilgrimage site Kundalpur (Bade Baba temple).The District has a significant of India's biggest cement plant and a number of industries and some small industries such as weaving
